A frustrating show. The anime takes the most generic Rom-Com characters and plot-line imaginable. It then expands the story, adding nuances and drama that bring life and interest to an otherwise cliched genre story. It then throws away all this hard work by making characters so one dimensional that they are insulting.
Your template: Plain-Jane girl swoons over genius handsome idol classmate. 
The plot twist: None, this is a romantic comedy and we already know they end up together.
The improvement: Girl gets guy, SHOW ACTUALLY CONTINUES, we get a view of married couple life and university life.
To insult the feminist within you: Genius-Handsome-Idol is as emotionallyapproachable as a waifu body pillow.  Plain-Jane girl seems to accept being ignored and general emotional abuse as OK because guy is hot, rich and smart. Show portrays this as acceptable and basically ends with the moral of "love can solve abusive relationships, it's probably your fault anyways". \n\n
To insult the man-isist within you: Dumb broad deserves what she gets; she has no problems deceiving and manipulating comic-relief-romantic-interest-male in a pretty disgusting way for her own benefit.

This is the most sadistic, unpleasant thing I have ever seen - on a psychological level - and I've watched those PEETA animal cruelty videos (and 'Friday' by Rebecca Black). What do they have in common you ask? They both make me cringe. 
The only reason I think I gave this anime a 2 is because there are moments that really engage one's sense of empathy - you laugh sometimes at the things that Kotoko does (if you're not cringing) and you cry. I really felt Kotoko's pain sometimes - and boy does she go through a lot of it. Perhaps one of the mostdisturbing aspects of Itazura Na Kiss is that it's quite dismissive of Kotoko's pain and doesn't really focus on character development at all. But then it does get difficult to feel sorry for someone like her after a while. How cool would it have been if the first couple of episodes were just to demonstrate how naive she was to begin with, and then she got it together became an awesome ball-buster of a tsundere?! It probably would have been one of my favorite animes ever. But unfortunately, as the episodes progressed it became evident that.. well, this is sadistic bull. It's really almost unbearable. The way in which Kotoko is treated by Naoki and the her utter masochistic behavior was genuinely horrifying for me to witness. \n\n
I hope that no girl or woman ever aspires to be like her; it makes me so angry that people don't recognize how twisted this anime is sometimes.

Okay, first of all, apologies in advance for the perhaps colorful language that I'll be using in this review.
This anime, while generally average, has the highlight of having the single douchiest character that I have ever seen to date. Seriously, Irie is so impressively terrible to everything and everyone (especially the female lead) that her own musings on her potential masochistic tendencies are less musings and more an exercise in stating the obvious.
This anime quite obviously tries to have an archetypical strong, silent, impassive and cold guy, but the creators obviously could not tell when enough was enough when adding from the 'cold' jar. Seriously,this guy is so extremely over the edge in the 'a-hole' department that he's in a class of his own. I seriously have no one else to compare him to.


This anime deserves credit for that, if nothing else.


As for the female lead, there isn't too much to say about her. Kotoko actually does manage to land perfectly in the center of her archetype, the 'always nice to everything and everyone beyond any sense of logic, duty or reason' hyperactive, cheerful kind of character. It's very easy to like and root for characters like her, but in the end she is rather forgettable. Also, my biggest gripe with her, is that I simply can not respect her. I pity her. Say what you will about having the single-minded determination to never give up on the man, no matter how rude and/or abusive he is towards her, but there is 'determined' and then there is 'self-punishingly moronic'. Watching Kotoko was painful, because in reality girls like her need professional help and a lot of support in order to get over the compulsion that keeps sending them back to their abuser and live a full and healthy life.


Surprisingly, the best part of this anime was its supporting cast, though that speaks more about the low quality of everything else.


I gave Itazura na kiss a 4/10. The animation was below average, the main characters were hilariously bad caricatures of people, and the plot itself was slow, predictable, and ultimately unfulfilling.


Props for sending young adolescent girls all the wrong messages, I guess.

Itazura na Kiss is an awful rom-com. It’s heavily flawed on every level and the ambitious premise doesn't make up for the horrible characters and misguided recurring themes in this anime.
Story (1/10): 
Itazura na Kiss is a story about how a unintelligent girl with no redeeming qualities other than being kind, relentlessly pursues her crush, who is a scumbag, and then proceeds with a long term emotionally (and physically to some extent) abusive relationship that is for some reason framed in a positive light. Sounds awful, right? I see a lot of praise for this anime comes from the premise, which is ambitious in thesense that it covers a long period of time and touches on romance past the usual "mutually confess and get together" phase where most romance anime end. What left a bad taste in my mouth is how Itazura na Kiss's narrative tries to portray a destructive and outright disgusting romance as something acceptable and even worth striving for. The very fact that this anime even exists is a moral stain on the industry.


Beyond this hollow and sickening take on what initially seemed an interesting premise, this anime still utilizes every shoujo troupe in the book but fails to execute them in a way that meaningfully adds to the characters, story, or underlying themes (which are.. problematic, to say the least). One example would be when they transitioned from high school to college, yet every character ended up at the same university in equivalent classes and situations. Even the one character who didn't make it into college conveniently found employment as a cafeteria worker at the school. Every "major" development was underwhelming and screamed lazy writing.


Art (3/10): 


I wasn't a fan of the art style heading into this anime, I find it wildly inconsistent and lacking any artistic direction, which is why I put off watching this for so long despite the intriguing premise. The male lead is the ugliest character in the show which I'm pretty sure is opposite of the intended effect. His mouth was way too close to his nose which just highlighted his stupid gigantic chin, but I guess that’s personal preference. The MC was pretty cute and the backgrounds were run of the mill. 


Sound (7/10):


I actually enjoyed the voice acting in this anime. The roles should have been easy considering how one-note all the characters are, so I can't heap too much praise here, but overall I thought they did well. The music was decent. 


Character (0/10): 


Awful, awful, awful, abysmal, trash, embarrassing, awful, and plain bad. The main two are the worst of the bunch, which should never be the case, and all the side characters were static and underwent absurdly predictable, cliché developmental character arcs, that were for the most part, just convenient cop-outs to force feed happy endings for everyone. 


Our MC is dumb, talentless, and unwaveringly in love with a guy who continually treats her like garbage and belittles her. At one point in the show she decides to become a nurse for the sole purpose of being able to better support her doctor husband. Eventually a side character points this out critically, but the show failed to delve into the critique as the MC never directly responds to the issue nor has any internal monologue regarding it.  I found their dynamic, and the show as a whole, to be incredibly misogynistic, which is very discomforting considering this a shoujo. 


The show never decides to really point out the self-destructive nature of her character and instead casts it aside in favor of framing her as a “spunky” good hearted girl and somehow expects the viewer to find solace in her simplicity. The worst example of this was when she discovers a side character in distress and then proceeds to completely panic and cry on the phone as the male lead tells her what to do, step by step, including how to call an ambulance. Bear in mind this happens in the latter half of the series which exemplifies her complete lack of development as a competent human being. 


The male lead is initially a “cool” jerk, which is typical in shoujo, but usually the male lead ends up progressively improving as a person as the MC warms his cold heart, so to speak, or they were always “good” and just not great at outwardly expressing it. This male lead in Itazura na Kiss is a jerk, and a truly horrible one at that, who doesn’t become a redeeming character until the last 2 or 3 episodes. On numerous occasions he shows some compassion but then consistently reverts back to his usual disgusting self. There’s also usually a reason, such as a tragic experience or difficult childhood, for the male leads initial behavior, but here the male lead has lived a carefree life in a traditional atomic household with his loving and wealthy parents. He has an amazing support system and the show never alluded to anything negative in his past to attempt to explain his flaws.


To sum it up, she is incompetent and he is lacking in basic humanity. I’m not exactly sure how these are supposed to be likeable characters.


Enjoyment (1/10): 


I did not enjoy watching this anime whatsoever. In fact, I watched the last 5 episodes at double the speed, as in I literally sped up the video 2x, in order to avoid wasting any more of my life on this irreprehensible trash heap of an anime. The misogynistic central relationship was frankly appalling, as was the lack of character development. I will say that the ending (episode 24; 25 is a light hearted epilogue) was heartwarming and enjoyable. At this point they are in their late 20s and the MC finally shows some fortitude that isn’t directly derived from her unsubstantiated romantic feelings, and the male lead finally shows respectable character traits without ever reverting. The problem with Itazura na Kiss is that it takes 23 episodes, or approximately 10 years within the timeline of the show, for these characters to achieve this minimally acceptable level of competence and humanity.


If you want to watch a terrible rom-com anime with unlikeable characters and misogynistic themes, look no further, Itazura na Kiss is the anime for you.

The story for Itazura na Kiss is quite cliche for me, it revolves around this girl who has a crush on a genius, to make it harder shes in the bottom group for everything and he's in the top.
She gets enough courage to give him a a note saying her feelings but being a snob he rejects the letter, then in a bizarre twist her house falls down and her dad says "well move in with my friend" his friend is no other than the dad of the guy she fancies.
As far as im up to you can see hes gradually getting to like her(very slowly) but apart from that the art is poor and the animation style is shocking, a friend of the main girl looks like a fat man not a women.\n
I would say its watchable at this part in time but its still got alot of episodes to go so i hope so more things happens instead of a predicted he "finally loves her they become couple".\n

It is quite obvious that when it comes to manga, womens don’t have too much imagination... I mean no offence, and I seek forgiveness from the entire feminist fanbase who will feel offended but this is the truth... Is enaf to read some shoujo and see that in proportion of 90% they are all the same thing... a girl who usually falls in love with a popular boy, the girl is boring, there is tons of forced drama that makes you wonder: ''Is this mangaka a virgin ? Did she ever was in a relationship or she knows everything from shoujo manga? Are Japanese teenagersso dumb in real life?'' Those who watched Kimi no Todoke (which is a good story) or read Ao Haru Ride knows what I am talking about (dumb melodramatic situations)... Basically you really have the feeling that those mangaka knows everything about relationships from other shoujo manga, this is the only way in which we can explain all those similar stories that lack originality, and are kind of like a new chapter from a really looong story, or another season of Young & Restless... Why do I know all of this? Well, because of some diabolic conspiration I end up reading a lot of shoujo manga (I am kind of embarrassed to admit it, but is the truth). But even if 90% is cliché, there is this 10% that really worth your time... So is Itazura na Kiss is in this category? NO. Well is a little complicated...


-  Let me explain few things before: this review will be about the anime, sadly as many may know, the mangaka died before finishing the manga (R.I.P), so I won’t bother reading something unfinished... The reason why I started speaking about shoujo manga is because the amount of shoujo manga that receives anime adaptations is really small in comparation with other genres (is actually something extraordinary if you have more than one per Season), and those who receive adaptations are usually from that 10% -


Back to Itazura na Kiss... I can’t really consider this story part of that 10%, because that percent apply to the last decade. Itazura na Kiss manga come up in late 90' a period in which anime industry started its grow, but it was a period in which originality could be still a big thing. Itzura come up in a perioud when shoujo manga didn’t had ULTRA-MEGA-SUPER melodramatic situations that would make you FACEWALL every 10 seconds, and would give you really dark feelings (cough* Ao Haru Ride cough*)... it was a period where many good shoujo started to emerge on the market, but it was a period in which many story’s would lack something important... in shouen manga for example there wasn’t a well-developed combat system (there was everything about martial arts and beams) but it was the late 90' where things started to change with aparition of much complex story’s like Naruto... Itazura na Kiss lacks something important too, and I will explain what a little later. 

This story is an important piece of the foundation on which later cliché where built on, that why I don’t consider this story as part of the 10%, being a classic, but that doesn’t mean is not good... is actually damn good. Even though the manga is old, the anime come up in 2008 (good year), so is quite current, it still have its old school aura trought, and this is what makes it stand out. 


Story: Before talking about story let me explain a really important thing. I saw that some complained about the romance in this story, that lack in comparation with story’s like Kimi no Todoke, Fruits Basket, etc. They are right, BUT this anime is not a shoujo romance, is a ROMANTIC COMEDY, the main genre of this story is COMEDY. What is the difference between this and romance? Well classical romantic comedies are: Pretty Woman, 10 Things I hate about You, City Lights (those are movies if you don’t know), romance is: Rome and Juliet, Titanic, Gone with the Wind... well is a little dumb to compare anime with American movies but is to make an ideea. For those who are used with the shoujo of this decade, and expect lots of development and melodrama, you won’t find this here... Those kind of peoples gave negative reviews to this anime, and I understand... they are like those guys who always watched movies where Arnold Schwarzenegger will fight against an army with machine guns, alone using a colt 45,  without being shot or finish his ammunition even if his weapon had just 4 bullets, and then he shoots a bullet in a car which explodes like a nuke and destroy a city... and those guys start watching a realist historical movie about WWII and complain that the main characters suck in comparation with Arnold, and the movie is stupid.

 THE STORY: starts with Kotoko, in the first episode she moves together with her father in a their new built house... but her father was too greedy to invest in good materials as a result the house falls apart in that night, after a 4 grade earthquake. As they remained homeless, she and her father move to his old friends which happens to be the parents of Irie Naoki, the boy on which  she has a crush and the one that rejected her love letter in just 1 second, because as he said, he doesn’t like dumb girls... Seriously if someone’s expect a serious romance after this synopsis or the first episode they have a problem. The story from then revolves mainly around Kotoko's effort to make Irie love her, gain his attention, and stuffs like that. What is really different from many story’s, is that this anime follows the characters for a period of over 10 years... Here is the little small problem that many complain, and the thing that this story lacks:  the development. Even though in those +10 years their relationship develops A LOOOT (I don’t want to spoil you), in the same time it doesn’t develop too much... The development exists in their relation and situation, but not in their romantic life or in their feelings. Even after 9 years Irie treats Kotoko kind of the same. Kotoko fall in love with him, in her first years of high school because he was smart and handsome, but they didn’t have an interaction until he rejected her, and after she started to live with him and his family. After she meets him her ideal image of him should shatter, as he is a total jerk. But her feelings doesn’t change, and remain as powerful over the years, which is really weird, because Irie is not what a woman would wish as a partner... of course he would be the perfect husband: smart, with a career and looks, but he would be the husband that wouldn’t make her feel loved, as a result she would cheat on him and divorce after few years, taking half of his fortune and probably their childrens and dog. Even so Itazura is a very enjoyable anime. The main genre, comedy, is not there without a purpose, is very funny. There isn’t too much drama, but in a weird way is so well played, and so emotional that I found myself with teary eyes almost every time.


 CHARACTERS: The main characters are obviously Kotoko and Irie. Kotoko is a dumb girl, but she is cute and honest. She is part of class F, which is basically, the class for dummies. She is technically good for nothing, she can’t cook, or take care of the house, she isn’t very smart, and she is clumsy, her only qualities being her honesty and stubbornly, which makes her a good character trough. Being clumsy and stubbornly, make her different from usual characters that would cry and fell depressed over every thinly difficulty (and she has a LOOOT, because Irie is... Irie), when a rival appears, she doesn’t back down and despise of her obviously inferiority she fights to win Irie. She really does a lot of things, and changes peoples, she is even able to melt Irie's ice heart (more or less)... Irie say at a point this about her: "Kotoko is unable to make 90% of the things I can do, but the rest of 10% I can’t do, she excels in making it.'' The problem is that we really don’t know why she loves Irie, he was her first crush, and he remained like this. After their relation develops, the emotional part remains kind of unchanged; she continues to address him as Irie-kun even after 9 years, even though at some point she becomes an Irie too.

 Irie is exactly the reverse of Kotoko. He is in class  A, a genius who is number 1 student in Japan. Very handsome (even though Kotoko is very cute too), cold and serious, he starts to change after he meets Kotoko... not because she change something in him (even though she does), but because Kotoko's clumsy action have repercussions against him. He is the main problem of this anime. He doesn’t give too much fuks on Kotoko at the beginning at that doesn’t change too much after he falls in love with her. He continue to be kind of cold, and bully her, or even hurt her (without intention trough), until the last episodes when he gets a little more warm and caring, which is kind of the norm in a normal manga, but at that point in Itazura it has been 9 years since they were together. You understand what kind of a cold bastard is when we see that a year before he had given her, her first birthday present (poor Kotoko trough that the man you love and loves you gives you a present only in movies) I mean seriously, it took him 8 years to give her a present ? Basically what keeps this relationship is Kotoko, and her "I love Irie and I don’t give up on him'' attitude, which makes her be extremely happy with any small proof of love she recives from him Q.Q (I really want to hug her now Q.Q). Even so, Ire is actually the portrait of usual Japanese male. Take out his looks (they aren’t all handsome) and intelligence (Asians are smart but they aren’t all geniuses), and you have the normal: cold, stiff and too serious Japanese husband who doesn’t say ''I love you'' but he show his love by bringing the money in the house.

 The side characters are important too. There is Mama Irie and Papa Irie, and little Irie Yuuki, who respects his onni-chan, and rejects Kotoko for a period, but continue to ''bully'' her, and consider her stupid even after he accepts her. Mama Irie, she loves Kotoko, and her main purpose in the story is to bring Kotoko and her son together, and after they get together she makes sure that their relationship works fine, following them incognito in the honeymoon, and dates. She is really funny, and she makes tons of pictures and films every important moment between Kotoko and Irie. But we don’t really get why she loves Kotoko so much. There is Kotoko’s father too, but isn’t too much to say about him. An important side character is Kinnosuke. He is the dumb guy who is in love with Kotoko. He is basically the male version of Kotoko. You may find him annoying, but you will love his honesty and motivation to do everything for Kotoko. He is the character that in the end receives the biggest character development of all.


ART: the art has the old school aura, is nothing special about it, but is not bad either. It suits the story, and the expressions the characters make are really funny.


SOUND: again, old school. The OP really remembers you of a 90' anime, and for me it was a surprise that it was done in 2008, because I really trough that is from the beginning of 2000. The ED are good too, the second ED is used few times as a sound track in dramatic moments, which made me laugh at a moment because it has rap, so I couldn’t really take in serious the moment. Nothing special about other tracks trough.


ENJOYMENT: I saw this for the first time in 2009 or so, and I loved it. I watched it again last week, and I loved it. And I am sure I can watch it again other 10 times, and love it just as much. This really easy to digest story, that will not give you sad butterflies in your belly, instead it will make you feel good. Is sad that the mangaka died before finishing the story (R.I.P), I know that there was more in the manga that wasn’t used in anime, including arcs and characters... I wanted to see more.


OVERALL: I recommend this anime to everybody who wants to laugh and have a good time.


  PRO: - really funny, and has great and enjoyable characters.

           - ZERO unwanted and dumb melodrama

           - Interesting time skip.


CONS: - I would loved to see more development between characters as a result of some important events.

            - The time skip can be a little annoying at some point when in 1:30 minutes goes 2 years, especially when it comes to Irie Yuuki.

            - Many of the important side characters have been ignored after some point and they didn’t receive they part/development/etc. in the story, like it was covered by the manga.

            - To short, taking in consideration that it follows + 10 years of their life, it really feels rushed and short, leaving you with the feeling of wanting more. An at least 30 episodes was more suited, 50 episodes would had been welcomed.



STORY: 8

ART: 7

SOUND: 7

CHARACTERS: 9

ENJOYMENT: 10

OVERALL: 9


P.S.: And for this who complain that it didn’t had development such as Kimi no Todoke, think at this: in Itazura the characters kissed like 3 times, and they did much more…. No kissu in Kimi no Todoke, +30 episodes , and no kiss…

For the MOST part, yes, I did enjoy this anime. The good outweighed the bad which is cause for my scoring.
The thing about anime's like Itazura na Kiss is that most of the enjoyment is spent on the "chase". The girl chasing the guy, the guy starting to realize his true feelings, the struggles of confessions and that is the exciting part. Once they are together it sort of marks the end of a series USUALLY and we are left to imagine thereafter for ourselves. In this case we get to see the aftermath, the adulthood and so on. This isn't always necessarily a badthing and for Itazura it began well, I was happy to see how it panned out, but there was a point in the lower half of the series that started to crumble slowly. The story went everywhere, the couples issues and resolve were sporadic and the time skips were placed oddly, making us feel like ALOT was left out. I couldn't help but lose the connection to the characters and the story. 


Irie-kun was a jerk, but a good jerk. He remains the same and even worse as the anime goes on. Only in times of need did he ever seem like he had a soul, which to be fair he did state he doesn't understand affection and how to express it but even for an anime it became far fetched. 


Kotoko didn't mature in the slightest and that is one thing that annoyed me throughout the entirety of this show. When she stood up for herself and got mad were the only times I could stand her (Which isnt a bad thing - its her character and I get that). 


What I couldnt take seriously was how they came to be together so quickly and the issues that sprouted once they were. It made no logical sense, the relationship and story started to waver. I enjoyed everything in between but the flow of the story had me a little dissatisfied - comedy was quite funny, romance was there when the climax hit but was lost a second after. I'm not saying this is a bad anime but it pays alot of MINOR flaws - nothing to NOT watch it though. The beginning is very good just be wary of the end sections.

First off, I'm glad I had this to watch during the time I was waiting for Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu: Purezza's new episodes to come out, and I would like to thank AlexisSolitaire for recommending it to me.
This has become my favorite romance anime that I've seen so far. It's everything a romance junkie like me wants: a beginning, middle, and end; an anime that's 100% romance right from the start and doesn't let go until the closing seconds of the 25th episode.
At first, I was under the impression that this would be a regular slice-of-life, high school romance anime. I could not have beenmore far from the truth. Not only did it begin in high school (at the age of about 17), it ended with the main heroine in her early 30s or late 20s. You might be skeptical at reading that, but trust me: you'll definitely end up loving it.

They utilized something at perfect junctures in parts of the story when it could have gone bad. Which usually leads to anime's giving themselves self-inflicted wounds by boring the audience it's trying to entertain half to death. What they utilize so magnificently is the time-lapse. I would have never guessed that there would be a time in my life in which I would enjoy a time-lapse, a "3 years later." Did they ever prove me wrong.


You know when an anime's good when I was completely satisfied at the half way point! About 14 episodes in! 14! I became skeptical again. Alright, so they've basically done all I've expected them to do, now it's just gonna get bad, how terrible. Again, I was proved wrong.


I like to use analogies to describe things that are tough to put into words; as most people might often do. Well, I attribute this show in this way:

Your parents give you $10 to go to the movies with friends. You're like, "Alright! Gonna have a good time. Night out with the buddies." Turns out, when you get there, you find you have an extra $20 in your pocket. Making the night even better. Then, you happen to be pulled into a side-room by Quentin Tarantino and given a private screening of his latest movie for free. You're thinking, "Wow. What a night: I got $10, found an extra $20 in your pocket, and I got to see a private screening of the new Tarantino movie! What a night!" However, your already fantastic night has one more surprise for you. Say you went with a few of your friends, one happened to be the girl you've always had a crush on. But, it turns out that after you walk out of the theater, she turns to you and says "that she's always liked you." How would you feel? How would that night be for you? Great, right? To a lesser extent, that's how I felt when this series was finished. Sad that it was over, happy that I got to experience something so amazing, and even more happy that I got to enjoy all these great surprises around each corner.


I would now go into each individual category and rate the show, but this show needs to stand out from the rest that I've seen in some form or fashion. It deserves no criticism, because, that's ultimately nitpicking for the tiniest deviation from greatness. (Plus, by reviewing most of these things, it would be hard to have people properly understand what I'm talking about or referring to without giving away any spoilers.)


It really did have a beginning, middle, and end. Not in terms of plot, which, of course it did, but the story of their relationship, the bond between the two is so fun and enchanting to reside over. I actually likened their relationship to that of one of those "well problems" that I got back in 5th grade: if you fall to the bottom of a 100 ft well, how long would it take you to climb out if each day you climbed 6 ft but slid down 4 ft?


I would wholeheartedly recommend this to any romance fan out there looking for an engaging story of what it takes to love and what it takes to be open to love. Although some might be critical of the "superfluousness" of the later episodes, who cares? Doesn't everyone ultimately wish that they could see their favorite couple from another show develop like this one and end like this one? 

It's a feel good anime that never ceases to stop "feeling good."


10/10, perfect, flawless, etc.


Feedback is appreciated.

If you want to be told more in-depth of why I liked the show so much, send me a message. However, spoilers will probably be dolled out like soup from a soup kitchen. So ask at your own risk. Or if you disagree with my opinion, and want to talk about the show, I would love to have a profile-to-profile chat.

I saw this anime a few months back and I loved it. I like the fact the story progresses much further than ending when the couple get together. It is one of the few romantic anime that is fully packaged with a solid ending. I like the 2 main leads particularly Naoki Irie as he goes through the most in character development. Soundtracks within the show are really nice and fit in with the mood of the show and the OP and ED themes are very good too. 
However this show is really targeted at the female viewers and is very romantic though it willtake a while before it gets there but worth the wait. I love this show from beginning to end. Even at the beginning when the male lead wasn't very nice it was entertaining to watch how his feelings gradually change almost episode by episode. It's very subtle. 


The only downside is the animation, it's mostly good but it does get a bit choppy and Naoki's character design probably suffers the most with this unfortunately. Overall, he is generally very handsome it's just some shots doesn't make him look consistently good.That's my only gripe.


I would highly recommend this show, there have been a few scenes which brought me to tears and they are not sad scenes but probably the romantic moments. This could easily make the top 5 best romantic anime out there currently.

   The characters are super kawaii :3 good looking and appealing, if it weren't for all the heart shapes and glitters the kissing scens would have been pretty sexy.

   The charecters: This is were things go way down!The main characters were really poorly developed, Irie-kun (main male character) started to be a mean guy who treats girls badly so i thought we has like a deep person with some dark past or trauma... but it just happens for him to be mean and thats all he is. Kotoko (main female character) just happens to be so obsessed by him that she is willing to accept everyting... There were time I just cheered up for side characters to conquer her because i couldnt just support to see her being more pushed down by Irie-kun.\n

_Itazura na Kiss_ is like a mountaineer who climbs up a slippery slope halfway and helplessly tumbles down to a crushingly disappointing death. Doesn't mean we don't get a few laughs when it hits some rocks and trees along the way, but in the end, it's still rather startling to see how low a series can sink from a promising starting point. 
Imagine a love story between a noble prince, whose only fault is his perfection, and a female slave on a pirate ship, whose only redeeming quality is the constancy of her failures. Along the way, our hero and heroine face earthquakes and dividingchasms, thunderstorms, battle of the gods, and epic Homeric warfares to test the quality of their love for each other. _Kiss_ is the modern epitome of the superfluous, overwritten romantic comedy. 


Characters? What characters? Characters are either plain-looking and stupid but kind-hearted, or porcelain-like gorgeous and inhumanely intelligent but cold and silent (on the outside, of course. "Deep down inside," we all know they are really lacking whatever it is that only the stupid, plain-looking characters can supply. Aah, the "secret weakness" that makes them human). Just mix and match those character traits between the sexes and you've pretty much covered most of the character interaction that can be found in _Kiss_.


The sounds, however, are excellent. The ambiance supports the circumstances rather unobtrusively, heightening whatever tension left in the poorly written script without bringing attention to themselves. The opening and the endings could easily chart my personal top anime soundtrack as well. 


Despite all its faults, I watched through the series rather painlessly, as much as I hate to admit it. _Kiss_ manages to stay faithful to its light-hearted comedy and well-timed jokes. Watch this to appease those dead brain cells of yours while eating pork skins and potato chips for maximum pleasure.

It's hard to find a nice romantic anime that isn't riddled with outrageous love triangles, harems, and cheesy relationship obstacles. Itazura na Kiss brings a rare story to the genre of rom-com anime. Paradoxically, it's a realistic portrayal of how romantic relationships progress and develop in real life. 
I adore this anime. I love romantic comedies, and I'm somewhat ashamed to admit that I've watched most of the shoujo anime that there is to watch, but Itazura na Kiss stands heads above the rest just because it's realistic and endearing. 
It's not overly sappy or cheesy, but it's beautifully romantic. There's not a frustrating endingwith you demanding more of the main couple; you get a sense of closure and satisfaction with how their lives progressed. There's a remarkable portrayal of the struggles that couples go through--not everything is black and white, and not everything is a fairy tale. I have no criticism. I loved every minute of this anime, and I've watched it repeatedly.

This show could have been great, and maybe it will be for you girls out there. I'm a guy that often enjoys Shoujo/Josei, but this one, I just can't even. It would have been great, but Irie is just such a piece of s***. Like he is literally worse than Hitler. Well, maybe not Hitler, but he's at least worse than Stalin. You'll keep on telling yourself as you watching, "Oh, this will be the episode when he stops being an a**hole." Nope. It never happens. And she's just so blindly loyal to him! Like get a grip girl and kick him to the curb!nope. This anime isn't disappointing, its unsettling. It left me with a bad taste in my mouth. I totally expected Irie to like see the error of his ways. Nope. And the worst part is that the show totally teases you, like an episode will end on a good note so that you actually expect Irie to be a good decent human being in the next episode. Nope. Sorry-not-sorry. Whats most unsettling is all the praise this show gets. Do girls really like guys like Irie? He's the worst! If you are a guy, at least, please do not watch this, unless you wish to be deeply disturbed.

Anyway... I just did nt like this, and it went on for solong with hardly anything happening, and then I skipped forward towards the end, and the plot had developed so dramatically.  No, I did not like this at all.

In a word : 'awkward'. 
Itazura na Kiss is an anime that wants you to genuinely care for the relationship of a girl with the intelligence of a sea urchin and a guy with a capacity for love equal to that of a dead fly. Worse yet, that riveting "love" story is set against the background of even more equally nonsensical and brain numbing tales of how two completely incompatible people can be brought together for no reason whatsoever. You will gain a new ability after watching this cocktail of outlandish romance - the ability to pulverise anything with a single headbutt. 
Warning, some SPOILERSmight be involved.


In summary, the male lead is an ambitionless, heartless and emotionless monster. Then there happens to be a brain dead girl who falls in love with him because he's "cool". Now how the lack of ambition, empathy and emotion can make one "cool" is beyond me but what follows afterwards is a story that was pulled straight from someone's ass.


In essence the guy doesn't give a shit. He treats her horrendously, humiliates her in front of others and generally waits for the moment to give her the slip. The girl on the other hand keeps repeating the same retarded statement all throughout the show "I love him, he's cool." That's it - end of story. 


Well, end of main story that is. We (the watchers) will still be treated to other anally extracted sub-stories throughout this 25 episodes of pure misery. A woman from the British royal familly marrying a Japanese chef (we know that happens every day). A perverted sensei who wants to get into the pants of his students. A kid who grows up to be an asshole because other people are... assholes. Absolutely riveting. In some cases, some of those sub-stories could have been interesting if executed in the proper way, Itazura na Kiss does everything but that however. 


The coup de grace comes in the last few episodes of this anally grand anime. Enter Keita Kamogari. The ONLY rational, realistic, and emotionally engaging character. The only one to truly care for another human being for what they really are. Nah, fuck him. Swept under the carpet by the writer like an irradiated cockroach. 


Finally, the drama that binds all these characters and allows the progression from one plot device to another just doesn't exist and when it does it's unbelievably superficial and feels as though it was written by a 6 year old. Same goes for comedy. It is by far the worst I've seen in any anime to date. As an example - in one of the episodes the brain dead girl is stopped, grabbed and nearly dry humped by a burly american policeman. When the emotionless monster intervenes it turns out she didn't understand him (the policeman) and he only wanted to know if she got lost. HA-HA-HA. Take notes kids. If you want to know if someone got lost, grab their arms, get as close to them as possible and thrust your pelvis into their abdominal area. 


The only two good points would be the art and sound. The OST did contain some interesting pieces, too bad they had to be accompanied by such an awful anime. The art itself was alright although it did lose its focus fairly often. The most well drawn characters were the sea urchin and emotionless monster. Every other character was drawn with less care all the way to the insignificant background characters which took on various shapes, from lamppost like figures to curious levitating black blobs. 


All in all, Itazura na Kiss is the equivalent of an exploding anus. It's full of shit.
